required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: The Influence of Injection Speed on Pain During Administration of Local Anaesthetic.
clinical_study.official_title: The Influence of Injection Speed on Pain During Administration of Local Anaesthetic.

lead_sponsor.agency: Norwegian University of Science and Technology

clinical_study.source: Norwegian University of Science and Technology

oversight_info.authority: Norway:National Committee for Medical and Health Research Ethics

brief_summary.textblock: This study will investigate the influence of injection speed on pain during injection of lidocaine. It is anticipated that a longer injection time will lead to less pain for the patient during the injection. This hypothesis will be tested on healthy volunteers, who will each recieve three injections with the same amount of lidocaine subcutaneously on the abdomen. The injections will be given over 15, 30 and 45 seconds. After each injection, the subject will be asked to evaluate the pain on a Visual analog scale (0-100 mm). The aim of the study is to find a simple method for pain reduction that can be used in clinical practice.

clinical_study.study_design: Endpoint Classification: Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Single Group Assignment, Masking: Single Blind (Subject), Primary Purpose: Treatment

arm_group.description: each participant recieves 3 injections with the same amount of lidocaine subcutaneously on the abdomen, given over 15, 30 and 45 seconds

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Age 18-65 years
Exclusion Criteria:
- Kidney, heart or liver disease
- Eczema or psoriasis on injection site
- Neuropathy
- Regular use of painkillers
- Hypersensitivity of Lidocaine
- Pregnancy
- Diabetes

overall_official.affiliation: Norwegian University of Science and Technology
